channel.title: sendQuest(sendQuester?

item.title: sendQuest(sendQuester?
item.dc:creator: @_Vengeance _Vengeance
item.description:
@_Vengeance wrote:

Wow…

for (int i = 0; i < 10000; i++) {
    try {   
        sendQuest(Integer.toString(i), i);
    } catch (Exception e) {
        System.out.println("Frame126 test failed at id: " + Integer.toString(i));
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}

Just remember, the client doesn’t support all the frames ( Some will cause it to crash - which the catch block will tell you )

Read full topic

item.title: sendQuest(sendQuester?
item.dc:creator: @mrX mrX
item.description:
@mrX wrote:

No it’s a way to find the ids. I set it running then it changes the default text of that id to the id so i know what id it is. But it’s not sending the id it send " + k + ". I can’t identify k like playerName i dont know how.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 25, 2008, 08:31:17 am[/size][hr]nevermidn i got it

	if(k > 0) {
	updateRequired = true;
	appearanceUpdateRequired = true;
	k -= 1;
	sendQuest(""+k+"", k);
	System.out.println("Writing "+k);
	}

public int k = 7500;

Why make it so hard when you can just do this:

When you go to a quest stage: quest2Progress = 3;

if (quest2Progress = 3) {
sendQuest(@yel@Quest Name, 180);
}

If that is what your doing

item.description:
@mrX wrote:

[center]I’ve just come up with.

	if(k > 0) {
	updateRequired = true;
	appearanceUpdateRequired = true;
	k -= 1;
	sendQuest(" + k + ", k);
	System.out.println("Writing: "+k);
	}

But it’s writes + k + at the id. Not the id.[/center]
